comment: Classical Physics might not be wrong when it says that electrons will fall into nucleus in some 0.1nanoseconds. We might be having wrong concept of time. Time may also be a Quantized entity and not continuous! The electrons will fall into nucleus if we update our concept of time. Quantized nature of time can be proved. To prove this, watch a movie that was released some 50 years ago from now. suppose it was of duration 3 hours at the moment of its release. If we watch this movie TODAY, it will take us more than 3 hours of TODAY! It means that we are not able to watch a movie of 3 hours (which was released 50 years ago) in 3 hours of today. This clarifies that TIME is PASSING RAPIDLY.  The rapid passage of time can explain that electrons can fall into the nucleus provided time start passing rapidly so much so that this phenomenon of electrons falling into the nucleus could be OBSERVED. Supposed a quantum of time is of X years, then, it remains of X years only as the time passes but every phenomenon might be having its own specific and well-defined time passage rate for it to occur...The phenomena of electrons falling into the nucleus would occur when time passes so rapidly that it becomes equal to its defined time passage rate...

In case it helps others watching, please listen carefully to the instructor's words at 44:18 (transcript below).  "Any frequency can't have an energy ... (you have to 'uh is) ... you don't have a continuum of frequencies that are of a certain energy. It is actually punctuated into these packets that are called photons." - Misleading, because it implies that it is frequency that is quantized and not energy.  The words "frequencies" and "energy" should be swapped around,  The correct phrase should be:- "Any frequency can't have an energy ... (you have to 'uh is) ... you don't have a continuum of energies of a certain frequency. It is actually punctuated into these packets that are called photons."

5:50 With all due respect this professor does not seem to have understood the reason why an electron cannot keep rotating the nucleus. A perfectly good classical model would be with the Coulomb attraction supplying a rotating electrons acceleration towards the nucleus exactly like the gravitational force works for the planets round the sun. However it can also be shown on classical electrical terms that such an accelerating electron would radiate and hence lose energy and quickly fall into the nucleus. This is not the same as just considering an electron at rest falling into the nucleus. A good example of a chemist not really understanding the physics.

7:00 paraphrased: "an electron would plummet into the nucleus in a fraction of nanoseconds due to Coulomb's law"  The reason is NOT Coulomb's law. The classical reason why the electrons should plummet is the classical energy loss due to classical radiation of accelerated (circular motion of the electrons) of charged particles. Without that loss, charges could rotate around each other like the Moon and the Earth.
Reconciliation with quantum physics and classical physics. Great class - a model for our future in these times.

Now she is saying that the electric field in a light wave is a Coulomb field.  It is not.  The Coulomb field is an electrostatic field.  The electric field in a light wave is generated by a changing magnetic field, not by a Coulomb effect.

Jeeez, she has simple stuff wrong.  A charged particle will not in general collapse into the opposite charge, unless the tangential velocity is zero.  What causes the collapse is that the particle is radiating away energy, something quite different from the Coulomb force.

The readings are from the required textbook: Atkins, Peter, and Loretta Jones. Chemical Principles: The Quest for Insight. 4th ed. New York, NY: W.H. Freeman and Company, 2007. ISBN: 9781429209656. See https://ocw.mit.edu/5-111F08 for more details and materials. Best wishes on your studies!

We do not have a PDF of the textbook available. It might be available somewhere else.

So I guess you know more than an MIT instructor?  Protons are positive and electrons are negative and so the force would be due to Coulomb's law from F = Ke (q1*q2) / r^2, where Ke is Coulomb's constant, q1 and q2 are the signed magnitude of the charges, and r is the distance between the two charges.  You cannot apply Newtonian mechanics here though, so F = ma cannot apply.  It's in the quantum realm and so you have to use probability, i.e. the Schrödinger equation.

@BitwiseMobile  “Blind belief in authority is the greatest enemy of truth.” Albert Einstein. Take the Earth and the Moon instead of an electron and a proton. They attract due to gravity in the Newtonian theory. (Einstein said that they each move without acceleration in spacetime curved by gravity). Would you now say that the classical Newtonian theory is invalid because the Moon and Earth would crash? The argument why classical theory doesn't work with atoms is not that the particles would crash because of their attraction. The classical theory would work if they would circle around each other like the Moon and the Earth if you are not taking into account that Maxwell's equations say that accelerated charges (circling charges are accelerated) radiate energy. The latter is the reason why classical electrodynamics fails. So the MIT instructors argument is flawed.

Well you are right  - that is what she should be considering. It still would not be stable and go on rotating,  because - on classical theory - it would radiate energy, lose momentum and fall into the nucleus. I can only think that she did not fully understand the problem herself.

Of course, light is purely a wave phenomena. Photons are not particles but the amounts of energy that electrons can emit or absorb when they change their energy, and hence their frequencies.  The addition and subtraction of energies follows from the fact that electrons are also waves and the trigonometric identities involving the products of sines and cosines.  I explain all this in my series starting with Demythologizing Quantum Theory 1: Wave-Particle Duality in Light.

You are correct, some images were not shown because of IP issues. All of our work published before 2009 was under a Creative Commons license (BY-NC-SA) and no exceptions were made for works that could be under Fair Use. If we couldn't secure permission to publish it under our CC license, we removed it. Some of the works removed were replaced by commissioned work that could be published under our license. In this case, this course has a number of commissions in the lecture notes. See the course on MIT OpenCourseWare for the full materials: http://ocw.mit.edu/5-111F08 As of 2009, we now allow for works under Fair Use.
